questions.text: Identify the abnormality:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morning glory syndrome

 

Option C:

 

The given image shows:

 

  • A large disc with a funnel-shaped excavation surrounded by a ring-shaped chorioretinal disturbance. Blood vessels emerge from the rim of excavation radially, like spokes of a wheel. Veins and arteries are difficult to distinguish.
  • Persistent hyaloid vascular remnants are seen as a white tuft of glial tissue overlying the centre.

 

All these features make the optic disc look like a morning glory flower, hence the name.

 

 

  • Morning glory anomaly may be unilateral and sporadic condition or bilateral and hereditary (rarer).
  • PAX6 gene mutation may be present.
  • The most important systemic association is frontonasal dysplasia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. OPTIC DISC PIT: An optic disc pit is a congenital anomaly characterized by a small, round or oval, grayish depression in the optic nerve head, often associated with potential complications like serous macular detachment.

 

 

Option B: Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a localized protrusion or bulging of the sclera (the white outer layer of the eye) at the back of the eye, often associated with severe myopia (nearsightedness) and thinning of the scleral tissue.

 

 

Option D. Advanced glaucomatous cupping: Advanced glaucomatous cupping refers to the deepening and enlargement of the optic cup in the optic nerve head, a sign of progressive damage caused by glaucoma, leading to a distinctive cup-to-disc ratio increase and corresponding vision loss.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Morning Glory Syndrome is a congenital, enlarged, funnel-shaped optic disc anomaly.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 774

questions.text: The ability to obtain an impression of depth by the superimposition of 2 pictures of the same object is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stereopsis

 

Option A:

 

Stereopsis- ability to obtain an impression of depth by superimposition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fusion – ability of 2 eyes to produce composite pictures from 2 similar pictures.

 

 

Option C. Amblyopia- partial loss of sight in one or both eyes in the absence of ophthalmoscopic or objective signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereopsis refers to the ability to perceive depth by integrating the slightly different images from each eye, crucial for tasks that require depth perception.

 

Ref: pg 408/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient who is on ATT came to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision and impairment in colour vision. On carrying out perimetry, bilateral centrocecal scotoma is noted. Which of the following drug may be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Option C:

 

  • The scenario given above is suggestive of toxic optic neuropathy.
  • Red–green dyschromatopsia is the most common objective abnormality of colour vision, but subtle (undetectable on Ishihara testing) blue–yellow defects may be an early finding.
  • Visual loss occurs due to damage to optic nerve fibres as a result of exogenous toxins.
  • These include
    • Tobacco 
    • Ethyl alcohol
    • Methyl alcohol
    • Quinine
    • Ethambutol
  • In most cases of ethambutol induced optic neuropathy, resolution occurs following cessation of the drug.
  • Before starting the drug, visual acuity and colour vision is to be tested, and followed up every 6 months after starting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyrazinamide: This drug is not commonly associated with ocular side effects. It is more known for its hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause various side effects, including liver dysfunction and hypersensitivity reactions, but it is not typically associated with the specific ocular side effects described in the question.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside, is more commonly associated with vestibular and auditory side effects, such as vertigo and hearing loss, rather than with ocular side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an antituberculosis drug, can cause optic neuropathy leading to blurring of vision, impaired color vision, and centrocecal scotoma. This is a critical side effect to monitor for in patients on antituberculosis regimens including ethambutol.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 316

questions.text: The type of optic atrophy seen in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consecutive

 

Option C:

 

  • The fundus picture shows retinitis pigmentosa.

  • There occurs consecutive optic atrophy characterized by waxy pallor of the optic disc.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consecutive optic neuropathy is a form of optic nerve damage resulting as a consequence of pathologies of retina and uvea. It is characterized by progressive axonal loss leading to optic atrophy, visual impairment, and optic disc pallor on examination. Management focuses on treating the underlying cause and supporting vision with aids if necessary.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 753

choices.text: Increase in latency only
Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude
Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude

questions.text: VEP in optic neuropathy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude

 

Option C:

 

  • Visual evoked potential (VEP) tests record electrical activity of the visual cortex created by retinal stimulation.
  • The most common indications in ophthalmology are the monitoring of visual function in babies and the investigation of optic neuropathy.
  • Interpretation - Latency and amplitude are assessed.
  • In optic neuropathy both parameters are affected, with prolongation of latency and decrease in amplitude.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase in Latency Only:

 

  • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye to the visual cortex in the brain.
  • An increase in latency means the signal is slower than normal, which can happen in optic neuropathy due to demyelination or other nerve damage.
  • However, this option does not consider changes in amplitude, which are also important in the context of optic nerve damage.

 

Option B. Increase in Amplitude Only:

 

  • Amplitude in VEP represents the strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex.
  • An increase in amplitude is not typically associated with optic neuropathy. In fact, optic nerve damage more commonly leads to a decrease in amplitude due to reduced signal transmission efficiency.

 

Option D. Decrease in Latency and Increase in Amplitude:

 

  • A decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission, which is not characteristic of optic neuropathy.
  • Similarly, an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy, where signal strength usually diminishes.
  • This pattern is contrary to what is expected in optic nerve damage and is not a typical finding in optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that in optic neuropathy, Visual Evoked Potentials typically show an increase in latency and a decrease in amplitude, reflecting delayed and weakened transmission of visual signals due to optic nerve damage.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 751

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral loss of vision with normal pupillary light reflex. Ocular evaluation was found to be normal. VEP shows extinguished response. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cortical blindness

 

Option B:

 

  • The given features are suggestive of cortical blindness.
  • It is total or partial loss of vision in normal appearing eye caused by damage to brain’s occipital cortex.
  • It most commonly results from ischemia due to blockade of posterior cerebral artery.
  • Macular sparing is present in occipital lobe lesions.
  • Pupillary reactions and fundoscopy are normal.
  • Visual evoked response (VER) examination shows extinguished responses .
  • ANTON SYNDROME – denial of blindness by patients who can’t see (lack of insight).
  • RIDDOCH PHENOMENON – ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malingering: wilful ‘blind’ behaviour, i.e. feigning of symptoms. On clinical examination, no ocular or neuro-ophthalmic findings are detectable which can account for the symptoms. Multiple tests like Prism test, Worth four-dot test are devised to diagnose this condition.

 

Option C. Retrobulbar neuritis: Definitive or relative afferent pupillary defect would be present.

 

Option D. Hysterical blindness: Unlike malingering, there is little or no insight into their infirmity in these cases and may sometimes display a complete lack of concern over their incapacitating symptoms (la belle indifference). May be associated with blepharospasm and lacrimation. Visual fields are concentrically contracted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical blindness is characterized by an inability to see despite normal eyes and pupillary reflexes. The disrupted cortical processing is evidenced by extinguished VEPs.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no:328

choices.text: Junction of optic nerve and chiasma
Junction of optic chiasma and optic tract

questions.text: This site of involvement in this form of defect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Junction of optic nerve and chiasma

 

Option B:

 

  • The visual field defect shown is Junctional scotoma of Trachoir.
  • It is the syndrome of central or paracentral defect the side of optic nerve involvement alongwith a contralateral superotemporal defect.
  • It occurs due to involvement of optic nerve fibres and contralateral inferonasal fibres looping forward in the nerve, known as Knee of Wilbrand.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve: Lesions of the optic nerve typically cause unilateral (one-sided) visual field loss. The pattern depends on the location and extent of the lesion but can include central scotoma (loss in the center of vision), altitudinal field loss (upper or lower half), or a complete loss of vision in one eye.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasma, such as those caused by a pituitary adenoma, typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, where there is loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Junction of Optic Chiasma and Optic Tract: Lesions here can lead to a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with or without macular sparing. This means that the same side (either right or left) of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions at this junction of optic nerve and chisama cause a junctional scotoma, which involves a central scotoma in one eye along with a superior temporal field defect in the other eye, reflecting damage to both the optic nerve of one eye and the crossing fibers from the other eye

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 789

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with a frontal headache and sudden loss of vision in left eye. He also complaints of scalp tenderness, noted while combing hair and cramp-like pain on chewing, suggestive of jaw claudication. On fundoscopy, a chalky white oedematous disc is seen. What is the first line management of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start on IV methylprednisolone

 

Option A:

 

  • The clinical picture is suggestive of ARTERITIC ANTERIOR ISCHEMIC OPTIC NEUROPATHY.
  • AAION affects 30–50% of untreated patients with Giant cell arteritis. Of these, 1/3rd develop it in the contralateral eye within 1 week.
  • A pale ‘chalky white’ oedematous disc is particularly suggestive of GCA.
  • Immediate systemic steroid treatment should be started in ischaemic optic neuropathy secondary to GCA, to reduce the risk of visual loss in the contralateral eye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Start on oral acetazolamide: This medication is used in the management glaucoma, idiopathic intracranial hypertension and certain types of altitude sickness, but it is not a treatment for GCA.

 

Option C. Start on oral prednisolone: While oral prednisolone is indeed used in the treatment of GCA, in cases with acute visual loss, intravenous administration of corticosteroids is preferred for its rapid onset of action.

 

Option D. Observation: This is not an appropriate management strategy for suspected GCA with ocular involvement due to the high risk of permanent vision loss and other serious complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate treatment with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is required in cases of Giant Cell Arteritis presenting with visual symptoms to prevent further vision loss and other complications.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 789

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who was brought to the hospital with complaints of increased thirst, extreme hunger, and increased micturition, with blurring of vision was diagnosed with Diabetes mellitus and Diabetes Insipidus. He was referred to an ophthalmologist and on examination was found to have bilateral optic atrophy. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wolfram syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Wolfram syndrome is also known as DIDMOAD. Diabetes insipidus, Diabetes mellitus, Optic atrophy and deafness.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kjer Syndrome: Also known as autosomal dominant optic atrophy, typically presents with optic atrophy but is not associated with diabetes mellitus or insipidus.

 

Option B. Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy: This is a mitochondrial disorder leading to acute or subacute vision loss, usually in young adult males, but it is not associated with diabetes.

 

Option C. Behr Syndrome: This syndrome presents with optic atrophy, ataxia, and neurological symptoms in early childhood, but does not typically include diabetes mellitus or insipidus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose Wolfram Syndrome in a patient presenting with diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, and bilateral optic atrophy, recognizing it as a rare genetic disorder characterized by the acronym DIDMOAD.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 790 – 791

questions.text: A 50-year-old female who is a known hypertensive presented with inferior altitudinal visual field defect. Fundus revealed sectoral disc edema. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ischemic optic neuropathy

 

Option A:

 

  • The clinical presentation points towards anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).
  • Occurs due to occlusion of short posterior ciliary artery.
  • Hypertension is very common predisposing factor.
  • Visual fields show typical inferior altitudinal field defect.
  • Dyschromatopsia proportional to level of vision loss noted.
  • Disc swelling gradually resolves and pallor occurs.
  • Consequence of AION: Pseudo-Foster Kennedy Syndrome: Papilloedema in one eye is associated with contralateral atrophy in the other eye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertensive Retinopathy: While hypertension is a risk factor for ischemic optic neuropathy, hypertensive retinopathy itself usually presents with different fundoscopic findings, such as arteriolar narrowing, hemorrhages, exudates, and sometimes papilledema in malignant hypertension. The presentation of an altitudinal visual field defect and sectoral disc edema is not typical for hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Option C. Optic Disc Edema: This is a general term that describes swelling of the optic disc and can occur in various conditions, including ischemic optic neuropathy. However, this option is too nonspecific and does not provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. Optic Neuritis: This condition is typically associated with demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis. It usually presents with vision loss, and fundoscopic examination might reveal a normal appearing optic disc initially (retrobulbar neuritis) or a swollen optic disc (anterior optic neuritis). The pattern of visual field loss in optic neuritis is not typically altitudinal, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify ischemic optic neuropathy in a hypertensive patient presenting with an inferior altitudinal visual field defect and sectoral disc edema, which are characteristic findings of this condition.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 786

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of a severe headache. She describes the headache as pulsating on one side of her head, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has a history of similar episodes in the past that lasted for a few hours to a day. Based on the symptoms, the clinician suspects migraine headache. What is the type of scotoma is associated with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scintillating scotoma

 

Option C:

 

  • Migraine with aura / Classical migraine is associated with scintillating scotoma.
  • A positive scotoma appears in the field of vision and while obscuring sight it has a peculiar shimmering character. It gradually increases in size until ultimately one half of the field is clouded, the fixation point remaining relatively clear.
  • In the dark field, bright spots and rays of various colors are often seen, frequently arranged in zigzags, when they are called ‘fortification spectra’ (teichopsia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma: This refers to a blind spot in the central vision. While it can occur in various conditions, it is not specifically associated with migraines.

 

Option B. Seidel Scotoma: This is a specific type of visual field defect associated with glaucoma, not migraines. It appears as a wedge-shaped defect near the blind spot.

 

Option D. Bjerrum Scotoma: This is a visual field defect associated with glaucoma, often arcuate in shape, occurring between the blind spot and the central vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scintillating scotoma is the characteristic type of scotoma associated with migraine, typically occurring during the aura phase and presenting as a temporary, shimmering, or flickering blind spot in the visual field.

 

REF: PARSONS DISEASE OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 95

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient with a history of RTA has multiple facial bone fractures with injury to optic nerve. The optic nerve fibres do not regenerate as they are not covered by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurilemma

 

Option B:

 

  • Optic nerve is an outgrowth of the brain. Thus, it is of CNS origin implying that it is covered by 3 meningeal layers and is myelinated by oligodendrocytes.
  • Schwann cells myelinate Peripheral Nervous System (PNS) neurons and a sheath present on these cells which helps in regeneration of neurons is called Neurilemma.
  • So, unlike peripheral nerves, optic nerve is not covered by neurilemma (so it does not regenerate when cut).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meninges: The meninges are the protective coverings of the brain and spinal cord, not individual nerves. While they are important for overall protection of the central nervous system, they are not directly involved in nerve regeneration.

 

Option C. Myelin Sheath: The myelin sheath is present in both the central and peripheral nervous systems and serves to insulate nerve fibers and enhance signal transmission. In the CNS, including the optic nerve, oligodendrocytes form the myelin sheath. The presence or absence of myelin is not the primary factor determining the regenerative capacity of nerve fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the optic nerve fibers, part of the central nervous system, do not regenerate after injury due to the absence of the neurilemma, which is crucial for nerve regeneration in the peripheral nervous system.

 

Ref: pg 179/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision and visual field defects in her right eye following a head injury sustained in a fall. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist suspects optic nerve damage and decides to investigate further. As part of the evaluation, the ophthalmologist wants to determine the total length of the patient's optic nerve to assess the extent of the potential injury. Normally, what is the total length of the optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5cm

 

Option B:

 

Optic nerve is about 47-50mm (approx. 5cm) in length.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The length of the optic nerve is 47-40 mm

 

Ref: pg 180/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient who came to the OPD had complete loss of vision in right eye. The lesion was suspected to be present in the ipsilateral optic nerve. What are the optic nerve fibres made up of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ganglion cells

 

Option B:

 

Optic nerve is the backward continuation of nerve fibre layer of retina which consists of 1-2 million axons originating from ganglion cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bipolar Cells: These cells are located in the retina and act as intermediaries between photoreceptors (rods and cones) and ganglion cells. They play a crucial role in the visual process within the retina but are not part of the optic nerve fibers.

 

Option C. Rods & Cones: These are the photoreceptors in the retina. Rods are responsible for vision at low light levels (scotopic vision), while cones are active at higher light levels (photopic vision) and are capable of color vision. They are the first step in the visual transduction process but are not part of the optic nerve itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the optic nerve fibers are composed of the axons of retinal ganglion cells, which transmit visual information from the retina to the brain.

 

Ref: pg 179/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which of the following is derived embryologically from para-axial mesenchyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Optic nerve sheath

 

Option B:

 

Structures derived from paraxial mesenchyme:

 

  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Optic nerve sheath
  • Extra ocular muscles
  • Blood vessels of- iris, ciliary body, choroid

 

Ref: pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of persistent headaches, visual disturbances, and irregular menstrual cycles. On physical examination, the patient's visual field is found to be compromised. You are suspecting a pituitary tumour. In case of a pituitary tumour, which part of the visual pathway is affected leading to the visual disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Optic chiasma

 

Option B:

 

The optic chiasma is located superior to the pituitary gland and diaphragm sellae. Thus, an increase in size of the pituitary, leading to it’s suprasellar extension compresses the chiasma leading to visual disturbances.

 

As shown in the diagram below, since the optic chiasma is located superior to the pituitary gland, in this clinical scenario of pituitary tumour, it is first compressed inferiorly so the visual defect which develops early is Heteronymous superior quadrantanopia which later on progresses to compress the chiasma from the centre completely leading to heteronymous hemianopia.

 

In the early stages we can differentiate 2 brain lesions causing visual field defects:

 

  • Pituitary adenoma: Heteronymous superior quadrantanopia
  • Craniopharyngioma: Heteronymous inferior quadrantanopia
  • Later on, both these present as Heteronymous hemianopia.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve: While the optic nerve can be affected by lesions or conditions anterior to the chiasm, such as optic neuritis or glaucoma, it is less likely to be directly affected by a pituitary tumor unless the tumor is very large or has an unusual pattern of growth.

 

Option C. Optic Tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasm to the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus. It is less commonly affected by pituitary tumors compared to the optic chiasm.

 

Option D. Lateral Geniculate Body: This is a part of the thalamus that acts as a relay center for visual information on its way to the visual cortex. It is not typically affected by pituitary tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that pituitary tumors most commonly affect the optic chiasm, leading to a characteristic bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the crossing fibers from the nasal halves of each retina.

 

Ref: pg 183/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: City university color vision test
Hardy Rand Rittler plates
American optical color plates test

questions.text: Identify the test given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudo isochromatic chart

 

Option A:

 

  • The given picture shows Ishihara’s pseudo isochromatic charts
  • Most commonly employed test.
  • Quick method of screening color blind individuals. It largely identifies red-green anomalies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. City University Color Vision Test: This is another type of color vision test, but it is not the same as the Ishihara test.

 

Option C. Hardy, Rand, and Rittler (HRR) Plates: These are another set of pseudoisochromatic plates used for color vision testing, focusing on a wider range of color vision deficiencies, including blue-yellow deficiencies, but they are distinct from the Ishihara test.

 

Option D. American Optical/Hardy-Rand-Rittler (AO HRR) Test: This is a revised version of the HRR test, used for detecting both red-green and blue-yellow color vision deficiencies, and it is not the same as the Ishihara test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the Ishihara chart is a type of pseudoisochromatic plate test, specifically designed for detecting red-green color vision deficiencies.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 326

questions.text: Identify the chart given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Log MAR chart

 

Explanation:

 

  • The chart shown is log MAR chart (Modified Bailey-Lovie chart)
  • There are five letters in each row.
  • The chart has a constant geometric progression, with the size of letters in each row decreasing by a factor of log1010.
  • The distance between each letter is equal to the width of the letter.
  • The chart used in the Early Treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS)

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition page 99

questions.text: The Snellen’s chart for distant vision was used to test a patient. He was able to read the letters on the top line of the chart clearly. The visual acuity of the patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6/60

 

Explanation:

 

  • Snellen’s chart is assessed at a distance of 6m.
  • If the patient reads the top line clearly (i.e., 60) at a distance of 6 metres, the visual acuity of the patient is 6/60, indicating that the patient can read something from a distance of 6 meters that a person with normal vision can read from a distance of 60 meters.

 

 

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition Page 99

questions.text: The given chart is used in testing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contrast sensitivity

 

Option D:

 

  • The chart given in the picture is Pelli–Robson contrast test chart.
  • The Pelli–Robson contrast test chart displays letters that have decreasing levels of contrast to their background. Thus, testing one’s contrast sensitivity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Color Vision: This is tested using methods like the Ishihara test, not the Pelli-Robson chart.

 

Option B. Distance Visual Acuity: This is typically measured using charts like the Snellen chart, which have letters or symbols in different sizes.

 

Option C. Near Acuity: This refers to the sharpness of vision at a short distance, often tested with reading charts or similar tools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the Pelli-Robson chart is used to assess contrast sensitivity.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington Page: 16

questions.text: A patient has come to the OPD with a complaint of blurring of vision in left eye. You are asked to test the patient’s vision using a Jaeger chart. What should be the distance between the chart and patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 33cm

 

Option C:

 

  • The near visual acuity is usually tested at a distance of 25–33 cm.
  • Near acuity charts usually comprise unrelated words or passages of text.
  • The charts available include:

 

The British N system

 

Jaeger text types

 

Education Objective:

 

When assessing near reading acuity, the acuity charts are to be held at a distance of 33 cm.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington Page: 15

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of difficulty in seeing the class blackboard since 1 month. Her visual acuity is tested using Snellen’s chart. In this chart, the lines comprising each alphabet have a certain breadth, which subtends a particular angle at the nodal point of the patient’s eye. What is the angle subtended?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 minute

 

Option A:

 

The lines comprising the letter have such a breadth that they will subtend an angle of 1 minute at the nodal point.

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. 5 Minutes: The angle subteneded by the entire optotype at the nodal point of the eye is 5 minutes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that in the Snellen chart, the breadth of the lines comprising each alphabet subtends a visual angle of 1 minute of arc at the patient's nodal point, which is a key aspect of its design for assessing visual acuity.

 

Ref: pg 266/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of blurring of vision since 15 days, noticed while driving. His visual acuity is to be tested using Snellen’s chart. The chart comprises of alphabets that are designed to fit in a square and subtend a particular angle at the nodal point of the patient’s eye. What is the angle subtended?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5 minutes

 

Explanation:

 

Each letter of the snellen’s chart is so designed that it fits in a square, and subtends an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that in the Snellen chart, the breadth of the optotype subtends a visual angle of 5 minute of arc at the patient's nodal point, which is a key aspect of its design for assessing visual acuity.

 

Ref: pg 266/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the ophthalmologist by her parents, complaining that she squints her eyes while watching TV and moves closer to the screen. Her visual acuity is to be tested. Which chart can be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Picture chart

 

Option D:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Snellen’s Test: This chart uses letters and is generally used for individuals who are old enough to recognize and verbalize letters, usually around age 5 and older.

 

Option B. Log MAR Chart: The Logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution (Log MAR) chart also uses letters and is designed for a more precise measurement of visual acuity. Like the Snellen’s test, it is not suitable for young children who cannot read.

 

Option C. Landolt’s C Chart: This chart uses a "C" shape and requires the test taker to identify the opening direction of the "C." It's more suitable for older children and adults, especially those who might have literacy or language barriers but can understand and follow instructions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the visual acuity of a 3-year-old child is best tested with a picture chart, which uses simple and recognizable symbols appropriate for the child’s age and developmental stage.

 

Ref: pg 268/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The storage form of vitamin A in liver is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinol

 

Option C:

 

  • Retinol: Storage and transport form.
  • Retinal: Present in Rhodopsin.
  • Retinoic acid: Inhibits keratinisation and promotes cellular differentiation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retinal: This is one of the active forms of vitamin A, important in the visual cycle, particularly in the conversion of light to visual signals in the retina of the eye. However, it is not the primary storage form of vitamin A in the liver.

 

Option B. Retinoic Acid: This is another active form of vitamin A, crucial for regulating gene transcription and playing a role in processes such as cell growth and differentiation. Like retinal, it is not a storage form.

 

Option D. Rhodopsin: This is a visual pigment found in the retina, formed by the combination of retinal and a protein called opsin. It is essential for vision in low-light conditions but is not a form of vitamin A storage in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that vitamin A is stored in the liver primarily as retinol, which can be converted to other active forms like retinal and retinoic acid as needed for various physiological functions.

 

Ref: pg 201/ / Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as the VISUAL PURPLE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhodopsin

 

Option C:

 

  • Rhodopsin is the photosensitive visual pigment present in the disc of rod outer segments. It is also known as visual purple.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Conopsin: Pigment present in cones of the eye.

 

Option B: 11 cis retinal: Vitamin A derivative which combines with opsin to form Rhodopsin.

 

Option D: Retinoic acid: Prevents squamous metaplasia and causes cellular differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhodopsin is known as visual purple.

 

Ref: pg 202/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: What is the normal dark adaptation time in any individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 minutes

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal dark adaptation time is 20 to 30 minutes.
  • It refers to the duration it takes for the eyes to adjust and regain optimal vision in low-light or dark conditions after being exposed to bright light.
  • Dark adaptation occurs in two stages:
  • Cone Adaptation: This occurs within the first 5 to 10 minutes.
  • Rod Adaptation: Following cone adaptation, the rods (photoreceptor cells that are more sensitive than cones and better suited for low-light conditions) take over. This stage can take an additional 15 to 20 minutes, completing the process of dark adaptation.
  • The rate of adaptation can vary based on factors such as age, the intensity of the preceding light exposure, and the individual's overall ocular health.
  • Dark adaption Curve:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the time course of dark adaptation is important for medical students, as it offers insights into the functioning of rods and cones in the retina and can be relevant in diagnosing and understanding various eye conditions that affect night vision.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Retinitis_Pigmentosa

questions.text: The ganglion cells responsible for colour vision is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) X

 

Option B:

 

X cells (P cells or Parvocellular Cells): These ganglion cells are responsible for processing color and fine detail. They have small receptive fields and are sensitive to color and the fine details of stationary or slowly moving objects.

 

There are 3 types of ganglion cells- W, X, Y

 

  • W= Receive impulses from rods. Responsible for night vision.
  • X= Receive impulses from cones. Responsible for colour vision.
  • Y= Transient cells

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. W cells: These are a less well-defined class of ganglion cells with diverse functions, but they are not primarily responsible for color vision.

 

Option C. Y cells (M cells or magnocellular cells): These cells are involved in processing motion and spatial information. They have larger receptive fields and are less sensitive to color, but more sensitive to large, fast-moving objects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X cells (P cells/Parvocellular Cells) are the retinal ganglion cells primarily responsible for color vision.

 

Ref: pg 212/Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The primary visual cortex is area_______:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 17

 

Option C:

 

Primary visual cortex is also known as BRODMANN’S cortical area 17.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Area 17 is the primary visual cortex.

 

Ref: pg 214/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The secondary visual cortex is area______?.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 18, 19

 

Option C:

 

The visual association areas of BRODMAN’S area- AREA 18,19 is called the secondary visual cortex.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Area 17: This is known as the primary visual cortex or V1. It's the main area responsible for processing visual information.
  • Areas 16 and 20: These are not typically associated with primary or secondary visual processing in the standard anatomical numbering of the cerebral cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary visual cortex comprises Brodmann areas 18 and 19 and is crucial for understanding the brain's visual processing pathways.

 

Ref: pg 214/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: All of the following are the primary colours except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary colours are:

 

  • Red
  • Green
  • Blue

 

Ref: 284/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The inheritance of colour blindness is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) X linked

 

Option C:

 

  • Colour blindness is inherited as recessive & X linked.
  • Abnormal gene is on q arm of X chromosome.
  • Colour blindness is present in males if the X chromosome has the abnormal gene.
  • The normal female cells have 2X chromosomes, one from each parent, and show a defect only when both the X chromosomes have the abnormal gene.

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION A AND D: Autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive: These are other modes of inheritance involving non-sex chromosomes (autosomes), but they are not the primary modes for color blindness.

 

OPTION B. Sporadic: This term is used when a condition occurs randomly or by chance, without a clear genetic link. Color blindness is generally not considered sporadic since it has a well-established genetic basis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing that color blindness is most commonly an X-linked condition is important for understanding its genetic transmission and for providing accurate genetic counseling, particularly in assessing the risk for male offspring in affected families.

 

Ref: Pg 292/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test

questions.text: All are tests for colour vision except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pinhole test

 

Option D:

 

The Pinhole test is done after testing Distant visual acuity of a patient. If visual acuity improves after pinhole correction, there is a refractive error.

 

The colour vision tests include:

 

  • Ishihara chart
  • Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test
  • Nagel anomaloscope
  • Lantern test
  • Holmgren’s wool test

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test: This is indeed a color vision test. It is a highly detailed, sensitive test used to analyze an individual's ability to discern color. It involves the arrangement of colored caps in order of their hues.

 

 

Option B. Holmgren’s wool test: This is also a color vision test. It involves matching colored wools under standardized lighting conditions. It's a simple and historical method used to assess color discrimination.

 

 

Option C. Nagel’s anomaloscope test: This test is used for diagnosing red-green color deficiencies. It's a more precise test where individuals match the brightness and color of a light mixture composed of red and green lights to a yellow light.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test, Holmgren’s wool test, and Nagel’s anomaloscope test are all tests for color vision, whereas the pinhole test is used for assessing visual acuity, not color vision.

 

Ref: pg 296/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: p arm of X chromosome
q arm of X chromosome
p arm of Y chromosome
q arm of Y chromosome

questions.text: The gene associated with red & green colour blindness is located on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) q arm of X chromosome

 

Educational objective:

 

The gene associated with development of red-green cones in located on q arm of X chromosome

 

Ref: Pg 294/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is derived embryologically from paraxial mesenchyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Optic nerve sheath

 

Option B:

 

Structures derived from paraxial mesenchyme:

 

  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Optic nerve sheath
  • Extra ocular muscles
  • Blood vessels of- iris, ciliary body, choroid

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Optic nerve fibres: The optic nerve is primarily derived from the outgrowth of the diencephalon, which is a part of the central nervous system. Thus, its embryological origin is neuroectodermal, not mesenchymal.

 

Option C. Ciliary body epithelium: The ciliary body epithelium, which includes the non-pigmented and pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body, originates from the anterior portion of the neural retina and the outer layer of the optic cup, respectively. This is also neuroectodermal in origin.

 

Option D. Melanocytes: Melanocytes in the body are derived from neural crest cells, which, like the meninges, originate from ectomesenchyme. They are not derived from paraxial mesenchyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the optic nerve sheath is derived from paraxial mesenchyme, highlighting the mesenchymal contribution to the structure of the meninges and their extensions.

 

Ref: pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6th edition/ AK KHURANA
